user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketBindAddress_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketBindAddress_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr)
{
    int                             os_result;
    socklen_t                       addrlen;
    const struct sockaddr *         sa;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    sa = (const struct sockaddr *)&Addr->AddrData;

    switch (sa->sa_family)
    {
        case AF_INET:
            addrlen = sizeof(struct sockaddr_in);
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case AF_INET6:
            addrlen = sizeof(struct sockaddr_in6);
            break;
#endif
        default:
            addrlen = 0;
            break;
    }

    if (addrlen == 0)
    {
        return OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS;
    }

    os_result = bind(impl->fd, sa, addrlen);
    if (os_result < 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("bind: %s\n", strerror(errno));
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketBindAddress_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    size_t            ActualLength; /**< @brief Length of the actual address data */
    OS_SockAddrData_t AddrData;     /**< @brief Abstract Address data */
} OS_SockAddr_t
...
#define OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6 
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
#define OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS (-34)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Fragments not listed have been reviewed and are not suspected of containing unreachable code: the AF_INET case (assigning addrlen = sizeof(struct sockaddr_in)) is a normal, reachable branch; the final "return OS_SUCCESS;" is reachable when bind succeeds; the variable declarations and type definitions are standard and do not by themselves introduce unreachable code. The listed fragments were selected because they affect control flow or are conditionally compiled (#ifdef) or rely on macros/expressions that could make code paths effectively unreachable or otherwise problematic (e.g. address-of expression inside the table access macro, the conditional IPv6 case, the default branch leading to an early return, the bind error-handling block and the cast to struct sockaddr). These are the code locations that should be investigated to determine whether any code path is actually unreachable in the built/target configuration.
